intro: Leucanthemum segetum, commonly known as the cornflower, is an annual flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its bright blue or purple flowers, which are typically 2–5 cm in diameter and arranged in a circular pattern. The plant has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are arranged alternately along the stem. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, making it an important plant in ecological contexts.
